title-group.article-title: Influence of O2-enriched intake air with CO2 dilution on the combustion process of an optically accessible spark-ignition engine

article-meta.aff: 1Mechanical Engineering Department, École de Technologie Supérieure, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Patrice Seers, Mechanical Engineering Department, École de Technologie Supérieure 1100 Notre-Dame W., Montréal, Québec, H3C 1K3, Canada. Email: patrice.seers@etsmtl.ca

abstract.p: Oxygen-enriched air combustion has been extensively studied, but not for internal-combustion engines. This paper presents how oxygen-enriched intake air influences early flame growth and the combustion process, and looks at how oxygen (O2) enrichment translates into resistance to carbon dioxide (CO2) dilution. The experiments were conducted with an optical single-cylinder engine instrumented with an in-cylinder pressure transducer and a high-speed camera to monitor early flame growth. During the experiments, O2 concentrations were varied from 18% to 29%, while CO2 was varied from 0% to 35%. The main findings are that O2 addition speeds up the combustion process and renders the flame more resistant to CO2 dilution. It was observed that the amount of CO2 can be significantly increased to reduce the combustion process to a level similar to that with air. Finally, laminar flame speed correlated well with early flame growth and fully developed turbulent combustion periods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Oxygen-enriched combustion has attracted research interest because of the expected decrease in carbon monoxide (CO) and unburned hydrocarbon (UHC) emissions. This reduction should be associated with an increase in nitrogen oxide (NOx) because of the expected higher flame temperatures. Adding oxygen (O2) to intake air should also increase the combustion propagation speed of the air–fuel mixture at a constant equivalence ratio, since it reduces nitrogen (N2) dilution.

Few studies have been dedicated to O2-enriched intake air for internal-combustion engines. For example, Kajitani et al.1 used a single-cylinder optical engine to investigate the influence of O2 enrichment on emissions and engine performance at full load. They reported that increasing the O2 concentration from 21% to 22% decreased UHC emissions by 25% when optimum spark timing was used. There was, however, a concomitant increase in NOx emissions. Infrared images obtained through the piston window showed an increased combustion temperature, which was judged to be partly responsible for the decrease in UHC emissions. Tests performed at constant spark timing also showed an increase in engine thermal efficiency for rich mixtures up to an equivalence ratio of 1.3, when O2 concentration was 23%. It was observed that, for a given equivalence ratio, the increase in O2 concentration was associated with a decrease in the combustion period and variability of combustion duration. Kajitani et al.2 completed their study, but at partial load and during warm-up. They observed that O2 enrichment resulted in shorter engine warm-up and that the flame propagation was stronger in the early stages of combustion with O2 enrichment.

Maxwell et al.3 used a single-cylinder engine fueled with methane or gasoline to study the impact of O2 enrichment. They reported reduced CO and UHC emissions, and increased fuel conversion efficiency when the O2 concentration was increased. They also reported a decrease in volumetric efficiency with increasing O2 enrichment in the intake manifold.

Ng et al.4 modified a car to enable it to run with an O2 concentration between 21% and 30% while performing the FTP-75 (federal test procedure) cycle. They observed, over the FTP cycle, that O2 enrichment offered some advantages, such as a reduction in CO and UHCs from engine-out and after the catalytic converter, especially during the cold phase of the FTP cycle. These reductions were, however, accompanied by an increase in NOx. Interestingly, they reported a marked reduction of olefins, ozone, and aldehyde, especially for engine-out emission.

Poola et al.5 also tested a vehicle over the FTP cycle with O2-enriched intake air, but only during the cycle’s cold phase. They observed reductions of 41% and 55% of converter-out UHC and CO emissions, respectively, with 25% oxygen-enriched air, along with a significant increase in NOx emissions. They suggested that 23% O2 enrichment could reduce UHC and CO emissions, while keeping NOx emissions manageable.

As shown by this short review, O2 enrichment can reduce CO and UHCs, but at the cost of higher NOx emissions. Only Kajitani et al.1 reported shorter combustion periods with stronger flame propagation. Most of the studies tried to show the advantage or viability of running an internal-combustion engine with O2-enriched intake air, but none really concentrated on the influence on the combustion process as studied with in-cylinder pressure or flame imaging. The main reason for revisiting O2 enrichment, despite the increase in NOx emissions, is spurred on by the trend towards engine downsizing among engine manufacturers. The goal of engine downsizing is to reduce fuel consumption while maintaining an engine performance similar to that of larger displacement engines by using a turbocharger and/or other technologies. It could be envisioned that a combination of technologies, such as turbocharging and O2 enrichment, from separation membrane, could help achieve a further reduction in engine size while delivering the same power. Furthermore, with O2 enrichment, high-load operations might not generate as much UHC emissions as with air, which would be beneficial from a pollutant emissions perspective. Experiments were therefore conducted in an optical spark-ignition (SI) engine with O2-enriched air under a high intake manifold pressure. We also studied O2 enrichment in combination with CO2 dilution to quantify its influence on the combustion process because exhaust gas recirculation is a proven technique to alleviate the increased NOx emissions associated with O2 enrichment.

This study’s objectives were (a) to quantify how O2 concentration influenced the spark-timing requirement; (b) to determine how early flame growth and ensuing combustion are influenced by O2 concentration for fixed initial conditions; (c) to establish what diluent concentration is required when O2-enriched air is used to yield combustion processes similar in duration to air; (d) to determine if O2 enrichment renders the mixture more resistant to dilution; and (e) to establish whether there is a relationship between combustion markers and fundamental laminar flame speed (SL).

First, this paper begins with the influence of O2-enriched intake air with optimum spark timing and its influence on the combustion process. Then, the same levels of O2 enrichment with a constant spark timing, allowing similar initial mixture temperature and pressure on the early flame growth, are studied. Lastly, the influence of adding CO2 with three different O2 concentrations at constant spark timing is studied. The experiments were performed in an optical access SI engine, which allows the recording of natural flame radiation by direct visualization.

sec.title: Engine
sec.p: The experiments were conducted with a single-cylinder optical version of a four-valve, pent-roof combustion-chamber Renault J4S engine that induces an in-cylinder tumble flow. Table 1 provides the main engine characteristics, along with engine operating conditions, while Figure 1 gives the experimental setup and typical field of view. A quartz window provides optical access to the combustion chamber, offering a 40 mm diameter field of view through the piston. The optical engine was driven by an electric motor at 1200 r/min throughout the experiments. A water-cooled AVL pressure transducer monitored the in-cylinder pressure and was synchronized with a 7200 pulse optical encoder mounted on the camshaft, providing a resolution of 0.1 crank-angle degree (CAD). The engine was fired in skip-fire mode (one firing every six cycles) to remove residual gases and ensure a stoichiometric air–fuel ratio. The results presented herein were obtained over an average of 100 fired cycles.

caption.p: J4S engine characteristics and operating conditions.
Experimental set-up and associated intensified CCD camera field of view through the optical piston.

sec.p: The pressure data were post-processed in MATLAB to obtain, for each individual cycle, the indicated mean effective pressure (IMEP) and mass fraction burned (MFB), which is a normalized apparent heat release computed from a single-zone model. In this paper, CAXX corresponds to the CAD at which XX% of the cumulative heat release has been released. The apparent heat release was computed from equation (1), while the coefficient of variation (CoV) of the IMEP was calculated from a net IMEP with equation (2),

In equation (1), dQ is the instantaneous net heat release, γ the ratio of the specific heats, which varied as a function of in-cylinder temperature only, P the in-cylinder pressure measured with the pressure transducer, and V the instantaneous in-cylinder volume. In equation (2), σIMEP is the standard deviation of IMEP and
IMEP
¯
is the average IMEP over 100 cycles.

The engine intake manifold was fed with bottles of O2, N2, and CO2, with respective purities of 99.995%, 99.9%, and 99.995%, while a split fuel injection was used to precisely control the amount of iso-octane injected to keep the air–fuel ratio stoichiometric throughout the experiments. The mass flow rate of gases was measured with Brooks 5853S flow meters. During the experiments, the range of O2 concentrations was varied between 18% and 29% by volume, and the range of CO2 concentration was varied between 0% and 35% by volume.

sec.title: Imaging
sec.p: Images of combustion chemiluminescence were acquired with an intensified Fastcam APX high-speed camera at 15 000 frames per second at a resolution of 256 × 256 pixels2, triggered at the spark timing of each fired cycle. A Nikon lens (85 mm, f/1.4) provided a 0.16 mm/pixel resolution and, depending on intake-gas concentrations, 50 to 100 images were acquired per cycle over 100 cycles. The images were post-processed in MATLAB, where the normalized flame area (Af,norm) was defined as the projected flame area (Af) divided by the maximum visible flame area (Af,max) of 12.496 cm2. Since the spark plug was not centrally located within the field of view and the flame was convected by the in-cylinder flow, the early flame was initially partly out of view for a normalized flame comprised between 20% and 50% of Af,max.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: This section presents and discusses the main research findings. First, the results with minimum advance for best torque (MBT) spark timing are shown, illustrating the influence of O2-enriched air on the combustion process under optimized ignition. Then, the same mixtures studied under similar initial conditions by maintaining the spark timing constant at 20 CAD before top dead center (BTDC) are presented. Lastly, the results of investigating the resistance to CO2 dilution for three different O2 concentrations are given to show how O2-enriched intake air improves the combustion process.

sec.title: Optimum spark timing
sec.p: The influence of O2 addition on the combustion process was first studied with MBT spark timing, while the isooctane mixture was kept at stoichiometric values. The optimum spark timing was found by maximizing the mean IMEP over 100 cycles for each O2 concentration. Using MBT spark timing translated into a location of peak pressure between 12.2 to 13.3 CAD after top dead center (ATDC) and CoV of IMEP inferior or equal to 1%, for all mixtures tested in this section. Spark timing is retarded as the intake-air O2 concentration increases, confirming faster flame propagation. For example, MBT spark timing at 19% O2 was 50 CAD BTDC, while for air, it was 23 CAD BTDC and for 29% O2, it was 9 CAD BTDC.

Figure 2 presents different combustion periods obtained with the in-cylinder pressure transducer (averaged over 100 cycles) as expressed by MFB and also obtained with the high-speed camera as expressed by Af,norm. Early flame growth is represented by CA10 (corresponding to 10% of the accumulated heat release) and by finding the duration between spark timing and Af,norm that reaches 10% (CA(Af,norm = 10%)). On the other hand, a fully developed combustion period is represented by the combustion duration between CA85 and CA10 and expressed as CA85-CA10. The figure shows a general decreasing trend in combustion duration as O2 concentration increases for all combustion periods, which is in accordance with the shorter combustion period reported in Kajitani et al.1 for MBT spark timing, but under different operating conditions. The Af,norm acquired with the high-speed camera follows the general trend associated with early flame growth from in-cylinder pressure data.

caption.p: Influence of O2 concentration on different combustion periods.

sec.p: Furthermore, it can be seen in Figure 2 that increasing the O2 concentration from 19% to 21% offers a greater reduction in combustion duration than increasing it from 21% to 23% or even to 29%. It can be assumed that, for cases with O2 deprivation with respect to air, there is a twofold explanation underlying the observed increase in combustion duration: (a) increased N2 dilution and (b) a reduced chemical reaction activity associated with a reduced initial mixture temperature due to early spark timing, required by a slower SL. These conditions translate into a 125% decrease of 0–10% MFB duration when the O2 concentration increases from 19% to 21%. A 10% reduction in the same combustion period was observed when O2 increases from 21% to 29%. Figure 2 indicates that O2-enriched air seems to play a more prominent role during the early flame-growth period than during the fully developed combustion period (10–85% MFB), since the combustion duration decreases by only 25% for the latter, when O2 increases from 19% to 21%. This difference, however, can be partly attributed to (a) higher in-cylinder temperatures6 during the fully developed combustion period with higher O2 concentration, which could increase flame speed; and (b) the difference of in-cylinder temperature and pressure at spark timing, which influences flame kernel formation. In further support of this observation, Figure 3 presents the early flame-growth duration expressed as CA10 as a function of MBT spark timing, along with a linear trend line passing through each O2 concentration tested herein. Since the CA10 can be considered laminar,7 a decrease of O2 concentration needs more spark advance because of slower SL, which, in turn, results in lower initial mixture temperature and pressure at spark timing, corresponding to a further reduction in SL. Therefore, O2 concentration plays a direct role with SL, but also on the initial conditions at which ignition is provided, which further influences SL.

caption.p: Early flame-growth (CA10) duration and 1/SL as a function of MBT spark timing.

sec.p: To attempt to explain the observed linear relationship between CA10 and MBT spark timing in Figure 3, SL calculations were performed for each mixture under temperatures and pressures corresponding to spark-timing conditions based on the in-cylinder pressure measurements, using PREMIX from the CHEMKIN package.8 The calculations used the high-temperature, iso-octane–air kinetics mechanism from Jerzembeck et al.9 (99 species and 669 reactions) and the PREMIX solutions were obtained with a grid of approximately 400 points, which is similar to the convergence analysis of SL performed by Conaire,10 who showed that between 300 and 500 grid points were sufficient. Because spark-timing advance is inversely proportional to SL, Figure 3 presents 1/SL as a function of spark timing and shows a linear relationship between the two variables. Moreover, by looking only at the data with at least 21% O2, it can be seen that CA10 and 1/SL behave similarly as a function of spark timing. It thus appears that SL in combination with pressure and temperature conditions at spark timing are, at least in part, responsible for the linear behavior between CA10 and MBT spark timing observed in Figure 3.

The general nonlinear behavior observed in Figure 2 translates into an increase average peak pressure (Pmax) and average IMEP with increasing O2 concentration, as can be seen in Figure 4. This can be related to two phenomena. First, the combustion heat release takes place more quickly near top dead center (TDC) because of faster combustion with increasing O2 concentration. The decreased combustion duration for conditions of O2 enrichment with respect to air (Figure 2) translated into a marked increase in average Pmax and average IMEP (see Figure 4). Second, maintaining a stoichiometric mixture at a constant manifold pressure of 0.7 bar resulted in an increase of fuel mass injected with increased O2 content, which translates into more chemical energy available for the combustion process. This is supported by Figure 5, which shows the relationship between IMEP and engine fuel flow rate, and where a strong link between the two variables is observed.

caption.p: Average in-cylinder peak pressure and average IMEP as a function of O2 concentration.
Average IMEP as a function of fuel flow rate.

sec.p: This influence of lack of O2 concentration on the combustion process is also felt between IMEP and early flame growth, as represented by CA5 shown in Figure 6 (some data omitted for clarity). It shows that, at O2 deprivation (19% O2) with respect to air, CA5 is reached over a range of 19 CAD, with IMEP varying by 67 kPa, while, with air, the range of CA5 is over 4 CAD with IMEP varying by 27 kPa. A further increase in O2 slowly decreases the ranges over which CA5 is reached and IMEP fluctuates. It is observed that the general trend between CA5 and IMEP for the case with 19% O2 is similar to that obtained by Aleiferis et al.11 under lean conditions and with a spark timing near MBT. This similarity can be explained by the fact that the influence of using a lean mixture or using N2 dilution is to reduce SL, which, in turn, makes the flame more sensitive to turbulence and in-cylinder conditions. Thus, this increased flame sensitivity results in an increase of cyclic variations of combustion and of IMEP. Furthermore, for the other cases, the lack of correlation between the two variables was also reported by Aleiferis et al.11 for stoichiometric mixtures and MBT spark timing.

caption.p: Evolution of IMEP as a function of CA5 for three O2 concentrations.

sec.p: While pressure data showed a weak link between IMEP and CA5 with 19% O2 and no correlation at all for the other conditions studied, the investigation turned to Af,norm at CA5 and a possible relationship with CA5 (see Figure 7). The figure shows that CA5 scatter drops as the O2 concentration increased, while the range of possible Af,norm increases slightly. However no correlation was found between the variables, as was also reported by Aleiferis et al.11 for stoichiometric mixtures.

caption.p: Af,norm at CA5 as a function of CA5.

sec.p: Figure 8 presents early flame kernel images at different O2 concentrations for stoichiometric mixtures and MBT spark timing. One general observation about all the images is that all early flame kernels reveal similar spherical progression, irrespective of O2 concentration. This progression appears to be a slightly wrinkled spherical flame. The differences observed due to O2 concentration are the time elapsed between spark timing and the first visible flame kernel, and the ensuing speed at which the flame progressed. These differences are considerable mainly for O2 deprived conditions, as was shown in Figure 2 for early flame-growth periods. The images in the first row of Figure 8 were taken with an O2 concentration of 19%, between 31 and 46 CAD after spark timing (AST), while the second row of images were taken with an O2 concentration of 21%, between 9 and 21 CAD AST. Finally, to illustrate the faster early flame growth associated with O2-enriched air, the last two rows are for O2 concentrations of 25% and 29%, respectively, between 6 and 15 CAD AST, and between 5 and 11 CAD AST, respectively, illustrating a much faster combustion process for cases with O2-enriched intake air.

caption.p: Flame images for a stoichiometric mixture and MBT spark timing.

sec.title: Constant spark timing
sec.p: Another way to study the effect of O2 content on the combustion process is to maintain a constant spark timing (20 CAD BTDC), allowing a comparison under similar initial pressure, temperature, and equivalence ratio. Figure 9 shows the initial flame growth for a stoichiometric mixture with 18%, 21%, 25%, and 27% O2 concentrations. The first row shows an initial flame growth at every 12 CAD, starting with the first image at 12 CAD AST. Under these O2 deprivation conditions, it is observed that the early flame is distorted; spherical flame propagation is only seldom observed. On the other hand, as the O2 concentration increases, the propagating flame generally becomes more spherical in shape and slightly wrinkled, as can be seen by comparing rows 2, 3, and 4 in Figure 9.

caption.p: Flame images for a stoichiometric mixture at 20 CAD BTDC spark timing.

sec.p: The influence of the O2 concentration on the repeatability of the combustion process was then studied by determining the standard deviation (stdev) of different combustion markers used to quantify the combustion process. The stdev of the CA10 and CA85-CA10, along with the stdev of Af,norm(10%) were calculated for each O2 concentration, and are presented in Figure 10. The first general observation is that the stdev is drastically higher when the O2 concentration falls below 21%. When the O2 concentration is greater than that of air, the stdev decreases slightly, showing that the stabilizing influence of O2 on the combustion process is nearly maximized. Moreover, the stdev of early flame growth and of fully developed combustion are nearly equal for stoichiometric mixtures with O2-enriched air. Other combustion periods were also evaluated and all showed the nonlinear trend observed in Figure 10. Finally, the combustion variations for O2 concentrations above 21% are constant and may be induced mainly by in-cylinder velocity fluctuations. This hypothesis is supported by the work of Enaux et al.,12 who linked the cycle-to-cycle variation in the combustion process to velocity fluctuations at the moment of spark timing. Similarly, Vermorel et al.13 showed, with large eddy simulations, that tumble breakdown induces high turbulence levels, which in turn influence the early flame growth and the combustion process from ignition to CA90. On the other hand, local equivalence-ratio variations are probably not a cause of the observed cyclic variations because it has been shown experimentally by Aleiferis et al.14 that a stoichiometric mixture, such as in the present case, does not correlate with cycle-to-cycle variations in combustion.

caption.p: Standard deviation of combustion periods as a function of O2 concentration.

sec.p: The influence of O2-enriched intake air on early flame growth (CA10 and Af,nom) can also be examined from the perspective of the combustion-duration difference, in CAD, with respect to air (21% O2). The combustion-duration difference is thus defined by equation (3) for CAXX and equation (4) for Af,norm as

where (CAXX) and CA(Af,norm=10%) of equations (3) and (4), respectively, are for any given O2 concentration tested herein. The results of both equations are presented in Figure 11 for early flame-growth periods (CA10 and Af,norm = 10%). As can be seen, a lack of O2 with respect to air is more detrimental to the early flame-growth duration than the reduction of ΔCA and ΔAf,norm associated with O2-enriched air.

caption.p: Combustion-duration differences for different early flame-growth markers from pressure data and high-speed imaging.

sec.p: The same comparison was made for ΔCA encompassing the fully developed turbulent combustion, as expressed by CA50-CA10 and CA85-CA10 (see Figure 12). The results show that using an 18% O2 mixture increases the CA50-CA10 duration by 17.6 CAD and the CA85-CA10 duration by 32.4 CAD with respect to a 21% O2 mixture, at which similar durations for both combustion markers are observed (19.3 and 16.9 CAD, respectively). Figure 12 also shows that adding O2 from the reference state slightly reduces the combustion duration, and the reduction is similar for both combustion periods, CA50-CA10 and CA85-CA10. These combustion-duration differences are similar to what was observed in the previous section with MBT spark timing.

caption.p: Combustion-duration differences for different fully developed combustion markers from pressure data.

sec.p: From these results, it appears that the O2 addition is responsible for a slight increase in combustion activity (faster chemical reactions) during the early flame-growth and fully developed turbulent-flame periods, which may also suggest a slightly faster SL. On the other hand, a reduction of O2 with respect to air slows the combustion process considerably, due in part to a reduced SL. Adding or subtracting 2% of O2 to the air does not translate into a similar change in ΔCA or ΔAf,norm. A short discussion of this subject will be presented at the end of the section.

Based on the results above, it was deemed important to investigate the importance of SL on the combustion process. In the first approach, SL was estimated for an initial stoichiometric mixture temperature of 400 K and initial pressure of 1 atmosphere by performing calculations with PREMIX (CHEMKIN Pro package8) with the high-temperature, iso-octane–air kinetics mechanism from Jerzembeck et al.9 (99 species and 669 reactions). Since the spark timing was the same for all the measurements, the initial conditions were also similar and thus, the comparison between SL for a given state should hold true. The PREMIX solutions were obtained with a grid of approximately 500 points.
SL calculations yielded two new variables. First, the change in combustion duration with respect to air, denoted ΔCA(%), is calculated using

where CAXX is the MFB duration associated with early flame growth (CA10) or fully developed combustion (CA85-CA10), while the subscript ‘air’ refers to the reference state given by a 21% O2 concentration. Similarly, the change in laminar flame speed with respect to air, denoted ΔSL(%), is defined by

where SL,O2 is the laminar flame speed for a given stoichiometric iso-octane–O2-enriched air mixture and SL,air is the reference laminar flame speed in air (21% O2). Figure 13 presents ΔCA(%) plotted against ΔSL(%). A ΔSL(%) value of zero corresponds to the air condition, while a positive value of ΔSL(%) corresponds to an increased O2 concentration (23%, 25%, and 27%), and a negative value of ΔSL(%) is associated with 19% and 18% O2 concentrations. As can be seen, the relationship between the variables is nonlinear. For O2-enriched intake air, each combustion marker is twice as small (approximately) as the change in laminar flame speed. For O2-deprived air, the trend is reversed, with the combustion marker duration increasing twofold with respect to the changes in laminar flame speed for 19% O2, while it is nearly three times ΔSL(%) at 18% O2. This trend is good for early flame growth (CA10 and CA(Af,norm=10%)) and for fully developed turbulent combustion (CA85-CA10).

caption.p: ΔCA(%) as a function of change in laminar flame speed with respect to air (ΔSL(%)).

sec.p: Figure 13 shows that, at 19% and 23% O2, ΔSL(%) is equivalent, but the resulting change in ΔCA(%) is not. The difference in MFB can be accounted for by examining the combustion phasing. With air and 20 CAD BTDC spark timing, kept constant in all experiments, the CA10 ends at TDC. When the O2 concentration is decreased, however, the slower SL results in a CA10 that extends into the expansion stroke. This, in turn, cools the mixture because very little energy is released during that early stage of combustion. The cooler mixture further reduces the ensuing combustion rate, extending the combustion process well into the expansion stroke. This can be illustrated by comparing the CA10 with 18% and 19% O2, which lasted 41 and 27 CAD, respectively. The longer early flame growth results in a longer CA85-CA10, which lasts 49 and 24 CAD with 18% and 19% O2, respectively. Therefore, the combustion phasing for conditions in O2 deprivation with respect to air enhanced the influence of a slower SL for constant spark timing.

sec.title: Influence of CO2 on O2-enriched intake air
sec.p: Lastly, the influence of CO2 addition on O2-enriched intake air was studied for the cases with 25% and 29% O2. Comparison was made with respect to air (21% O2), which, in this section, is the reference state. The engine conditions were the same as previously, namely a constant spark timing of 20 CAD BTDC and a stoichiometric iso-octane–air mixture. Because of the spark timing used in this experiment, it was decided not to test a mixture made of 29% O2 and 0% CO2 in order to prevent damaging the engine with high in-cylinder pressure.

Figure 14 presents the influence of CO2 concentration in O2-enriched intake air with in-cylinder pressure data for early flame growth and fully developed turbulent combustion periods. The duration differences along the ordinate were computed using equation (3) above. The results show that, at 25% O2, a concentration of approximately 13% of CO2 is needed to have a CA10 duration similar to that of the reference state, while 15% CO2 is needed for 29% O2-enriched air. The results are similar for fully developed turbulent combustion expressed by CA85-CA10. Furthermore, nonlinear behavior is observed when a high concentration of CO2 is reached in the case of 29% O2-enriched air. This behavior is due, in part, to the combustion phasing when the combustion durations for the 29% O2/35% CO2 mixture are similar to the case with 19% O2, presented above, with CA10 ending slightly ATDC. The combustion phasing for the 25% O2/25% CO2 mixture is similar to that for air. Therefore, another possible contributing factor for the nonlinear behavior might be CO2 dissociation at high temperatures, which in turn affects SL. Indeed, Halter et al.15 observed a nonlinear behavior of SL experimentally and numerically in the presence of CO2 dilution. They linked this behavior to the fact that CO2 addition increases the mixture’s specific heat capacity and also influences the chemical reactions because of CO2 dissociation at high temperatures. In Halter et al.,15 CO2 dissociation contributed between 50% and 25% of the observed reduction in stoichiometric iso-octane–air laminar flame speed when a 5% to 20% CO2 dilution was used, respectively.

caption.p: Early flame-growth and fully developed combustion-duration differences with respect to the reference state as a function of CO2 concentration.

sec.p: In an attempt to reduce all the data with the same spark timing (same initial conditions), ΔSL, given by equation (7), was computed based on the laminar flame speed for a constant O2 concentration but varying CO2 concentration (SL), and on a reference laminar flame speed having the same O2 concentrations given by SL,ref.
For example, for the influence of CO2 at 29% O2, the reference mixture is 29% O2/5% CO2. The same reference was used for the difference in combustion periods, ΔCA given by

The reference mixture for each set of experiments is presented in Table 2, with the resulting plot for ΔCA10 and Δ(CA85-CA10) in Figure 15, along with a trend line passing through all the data points and the origin. It can be seen that all the data points for the influence of CO2 on early flame growth fall nearly on a single curve, irrespective of O2 concentration. This shows that the difference in CO2 concentration results in a similar reduction of SL, regardless of the O2 concentration in the air mixture. This, in turn, similarly changed the combustion process in the engine, as expressed by MFB. This observation is limited to the concentrations presented in this section. It also illustrates the strong relationship between laminar flame speed and the combustion process within the engine.

caption.p: Reference mixture for each set of experimental data in Figure 15.

tr.td: Influence of CO2 concentration at 21% O2
Influence of CO2 concentration at 25% O2
Influence of CO2 concentration at 29% O2

caption.p: ΔCA10 and Δ(CA85-CA10) as a function of ΔSL.

sec.p: Furthermore, for those operating conditions, CA85-CA10 and CA10 have similar durations, which accounts for the similar ΔCA observed in Figures 14 and 15 with the two combustion periods. While Heywood7 identified the CA10 as being flame propagation in the laminar regime, the link between the CA85-CA10 and SL is not surprising, since the turbulent flame speed associated with this combustion period is often expressed as a function of laminar flame speed and turbulence intensity (Linse et al.16 and Landry et al.17) in modeling internal-combustion engines. Since engine speed was kept constant, the turbulence intensity was also similar from one experiment to the next. Consequently, the fully developed combustion difference can therefore be associated with the change in laminar flame speed due to variations in CO2 and O2 concentrations.

Finally, the advantage of increasing O2 concentration above the reference state is increased resistance to CO2 dilution. With air, a maximum CO2 concentration of 10–15% is achieved experimentally, attaining 25% and 35% when the O2 concentration is 25% and 29%, respectively. Therefore, the higher O2 content makes the flame more resistant to dilution because of enhanced laminar flame speed and higher flame temperature. Chen and Axelbaum18 identified the H + O2→ OH + O reaction as being beneficial to flame resistance to extinction because of the higher flame temperature associated with the O2-enriched air. The calculations performed herein with PREMIX for SL support this affirmation. For example, the flame temperature of 25%O2 / 25% CO2 / iso-octane mixture is 100 K higher than the 21% O2 / 10% CO2 / iso-octane mixture. The temperature difference for the 29%O2 / 35% CO2 / iso-octane mixture reached 200 K.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Experiments were conducted with an optically accessible single-cylinder engine fed with different stoichiometric iso-octane / O2-enriched air mixtures. Experiments conducted with O2-enriched air and MBT spark timing resulted in faster flame propagation, which can be linked to increased laminar flame speed and initial mixture temperature at spark timing. When O2 deprivation, with respect to air, is used, the combustion process is similar to the lean combustion mixtures reported in the literature.

A second set of experiments at constant spark timing with different O2-enriched intake air mixtures was then presented. High-speed imaging and in-cylinder pressure data revealed that the lack of O2 has a greater impact on the combustion process than O2-enriched air. This behavior can be linked to combustion phasing, which further influences the combustion process for slow SL. Furthermore, a nonlinear relationship between the difference in combustion period with respect to air (ΔCA(%)) and a difference in laminar flame speed with respect to air (ΔSL(%)) was observed, which indicates that the laminar flame speed variation is approximately twice as fast as the MFB duration variation for O2-enriched air, while the MFB duration variation is at least twice as fast as the variation in laminar flame speed for the lack of O2.

Finally, two O2-enriched air mixtures with CO2 dilution were compared to air/CO2 dilution. It was observed that O2-enriched air allows an increased CO2 dilution tolerance with respect to air. For example, 25% O2-enriched air needs approximately 13% CO2 to achieve a combustion duration similar to air, while 25% CO2 is needed to observe combustion deterioration. When air is used, only 10–15% CO2 is needed to observe combustion deterioration. The increased tolerance to dilution in the presence of O2-enriched air may be related to higher SL and flame temperature.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: Af projected flame area
Af,max maximum projected flame area
Af,norm normalized flame area
P in-cylinder pressure
Pmax peak pressure
SL laminar flame speed
SL,air laminar flame speed of iso-octane/air
SL,ref laminar flame speed of reference
V instantaneous in-cylinder volume
ΔAf,norm combustion-duration difference of Af,norm
ΔCA combustion-duration difference of CAXX
ΔCA(%) change of combustion-duration marker (mass fraction burned) with respect to air condition
ΔSL laminar flame speed difference
ΔSL(%) change of laminar flame speed with respect to air condition

sec.title: Abbreviations
sec.p: AST after spark timing
ATDC after top dead center
BTDC before top dead center
CAD crank-angle degree
CAXX crank angle degree for which XX% of the cumulative heat release is released
CO carbon monoxide
CO2 carbon dioxide
CoV coefficient of variation
FTP federal test procedure
IMEP indicated mean effective pressure
MBT minimum advance for best torque
MFB mass fraction burned
N2 nitrogen
NOx nitrogen oxide
O2 oxygen
SI spark ignition
stdev standard deviation
TDC top dead center
UHC unburned hydrocarbon
